docs.lead_paragraph: Authorities in Idaho have arrested the driver thought to have abandoned a trailer containing 37,000 pounds of rotten chicken at a western Montana truck stop.

headline.main: Driver Accused of Abandoning Chicken Truck Found
headline.print_headline: Driver Accused of Abandoning Chicken Truck Found

docs.lead_paragraph: One of the most highly contentious Obamacare programs, which calls on states to expand their publicly-funded healthcare for the poor, could see a second wave of participation by U.S. states later this year or early in 2015, according to state officials and independent analysts.

headline.main: Factbox: Obamacare Could See Second Wave of Medicaid Expansion
headline.print_headline: Factbox: Obamacare Could See Second Wave of Medicaid Expansion

docs.lead_paragraph: Maureen Stefanides wanted to fulfill her father’s request after long nursing home stays left him weak and unhappy, but the forces of the health care system seemed stacked against her.

headline.main: Fighting to Honor a Father’s Last Wish: To Die at Home
headline.print_headline: A Father’s Last Wish, and a Daughter’s Anguish

docs.abstract: Institute of Medicine report calls for fundamental overhaul of country's end-of-life care; highlights plight of Maureen Stefanides and her unsuccessful struggle against the health care system to fulfill her father Joseph Andrey's dearest wish to die at home.
docs.snippet: Maureen Stefanides wanted to fulfill her father’s request after long nursing home stays left him weak and unhappy, but the forces of the health care system seemed stacked against her.

docs.lead_paragraph: “The Equalizer” stars Denzel Washington as a seemingly bookish man who turns out to be an assassin on behalf of the wronged.

headline.seo: Denzel Washington Exacts Vengeance in ‘The Equalizer’
headline.print_headline: Kind, and Handy With a Corkscrew

docs.abstract: A O Scott reviews movie The Equalizer, directed by Antoine Fuqua and starring Denzel Washington.
docs.snippet: “The Equalizer” stars Denzel Washington as a seemingly bookish man who turns out to be an assassin on behalf of the wronged.

docs.lead_paragraph: More than a dozen U.S. senators from both parties are calling on the Obama administration to broaden a Medicaid program for the nation's frailest seniors, calling it a proven alternative to pricier nursing home care as states seek to limit long-term medical costs.

headline.main: Senators: Widen Medicaid Program for Frail Seniors
headline.print_headline: Senators: Widen Medicaid Program for Frail Seniors

docs.lead_paragraph: UnitedHealth Group Inc. has sued two brothers who ran a company that promoted Lap-Band weight-loss surgery, accusing the pair of defrauding the insurer of more than $40 million through a complex billing scheme.
docs.snippet: UnitedHealth Group Inc. has sued two brothers who ran a company that promoted Lap-Band weight-loss surgery, accusing the pair of defrauding the insurer of more than $40 million through a complex billing scheme.

docs.lead_paragraph: Financial reports from investor-owned hospitals and surveys by several state hospital associations show that Medicaid expansion has reduced the number of patients who cannot pay their bills.

headline.main: Affordable Care Act Reduces Costs for Hospitals, Report Says
headline.print_headline: Health Act Reduces Costs for Hospitals, Report Says

docs.abstract: Obama administration increases pressure on states to expand Medicaid, citing new evidence that hospitals reap financial benefits and gain more paying customers when states broaden eligibility.
docs.snippet: Financial reports from investor-owned hospitals and surveys by several state hospital associations show that Medicaid expansion has reduced the number of patients who cannot pay their bills.

docs.lead_paragraph: In a system where a primary surgeon gets paid $6,200 and an assistant gets $117,000 for work on the same operation, patients need more information in how they are going to be charged.
docs.abstract: Editorial supports New York State law, scheduled to take effect March 2015, requiring insurers to notify patients in advance on whether health care providers treating them will be in or out of network; notes cases in which patients have been billed by out of network doctors for costly services that they did not request, or, in some cases, receive; calls for other states to follow New York's lead.
docs.snippet: In a system where a primary surgeon gets paid $6,200 and an assistant gets $117,000 for work on the same operation, patients need more information in how they are going to be charged.

docs.lead_paragraph: An unintended disclosure of documents from the Republican Governors Association opens a window onto corporate donors and the size of their checks.

headline.main: G.O.P. Error Reveals Donors and the Price of Access
headline.print_headline: G.O.P. Error Reveals Donors and the Price of Access

docs.abstract: Unintended disclosure of documents from Republican Governors Association opens window onto corporate donors and size of their checks; documents show that many of America's most prominent companies, from Aetna to Walmart, have poured millions of dollars into campaigns of GOP governors since 2008.
docs.snippet: An unintended disclosure of documents from the Republican Governors Association opens a window onto corporate donors and the size of their checks.

keywords.value: Citizens for Responsibility and Ethics in Washington
keywords.name: organizations

docs.lead_paragraph: A truck dripping rancid juices from thousands of pounds of rotting chicken sat in the heat attracting flies Thursday at a western Montana truck stop, where an Idaho trucking company employee abandoned it.

headline.main: Abandoned Truck Dripping Rancid Chicken Juice
headline.print_headline: Abandoned Truck Dripping Rancid Chicken Juice

docs.snippet: A truck dripping rancid juices from thousands of pounds of rotting chicken sat in the heat attracting flies Thursday at a western Montana truck stop, where an Idaho trucking company employee abandoned it.
